questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 1:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the names given to the children and the emotional tone of the LORD's words.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD said to him' (v.1, 3, 5, 7)
Pay attention to the names: Jezreel, No Mercy, Not My People
Notice the shift from judgment to hope in the final verse (v.10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being tested (Hosea), WHAT God commands (to marry a wife of whoredom and have children), WHERE it happens (in the land of Israel), and WHY (because the house of Israel is unfaithful).
tips: Hosea takes Gomer (v.2)
The children: Jezreel (v.3), No Mercy (v.5), Not My People (v.6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the naming of the children (Jezreel, No Mercy, Not My People), the LORD's declaration about the land (v.10), or the contrast between 'you are not my people' and 'children of the living God'?
tips: The name 'Jezreel' points to the punishment of the house of Jehu (v.3)
The name 'No Mercy' shows God's judgment on the unfaithful (v.5)
The final declaration that they become 'children of the living God' despite being 'not my people' (v.10)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: The unfaithfulness of northern Israel (the 'whoredom') leads to God's judgment
But God's love remains and He will restore them to be His people
This is a picture of Christ's love for the church which is unfaithful

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to marry a wife of whoredom? The meaning of the names? The shift from judgment to hope?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern context, a 'wife of whoredom' was a symbol of unfaithfulness, not a literal promiscuous woman
The name 'Jezreel' refers to the blood of Jezreel (a king who murdered 1850 people) and the punishment for that bloodshed
The phrase 'you are not my people' is a declaration of judgment, but the reversal to 'children of the living God' shows God's covenant love

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Hosea's marriage to Gomer pictures God's love for an unfaithful people. What area of your life requires God to be your 'LORD' (as in the covenant) this week?
tips: Think about how you've been unfaithful to God (like Israel)
Pray for the grace to be 'children of the living God' in your life
Ask God to help you be faithful in a world that is unfaithful

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His faithfulness to His unfaithful people. Ask for the courage to be His people.
tips: Thank God that even when we are unfaithful, He remains our God
Pray for the grace to be 'children of the living God'
Ask God to help us to be faithful in a world that is unfaithful

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 2:1-19 aloud, focusing on the dialogue in verses 2-4 and the description of the wilderness in verses 14-15.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I will' in verses 2, 4, 14, 15
Emphasize the contrast between the current state and the future restoration in verses 14-15
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the 'whoring' description in verse 2

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is unfaithful, WHAT they have done, WHERE this is happening (in the context of northern Israel), and WHY God is reacting.
tips: Include the metaphor of Israel as a wife who has been unfaithful
Note the consequences: stripping naked and making her like wilderness
Mention the call to return and the new betrothal

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out the most? Consider: the call to put away the whoring (v.2), the image of the wilderness (v.2), or the new betrothal (v.14-15)?
tips: The phrase 'I will betroth you to me in righteousness and in justice' (v.14) shows God's commitment to restore
The image of the wilderness (v.2) as a place of desolation and separation
The promise of 'forever' in the new betrothal (v.14)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: Hosea is warning of the consequences of Israel's spiritual adultery but also promising a restoration through God's love
The restoration is not a return to old ways but a new covenant of faithfulness
This passage foreshadows Christ as the true husband who betroths His church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'whoring' (v.2), the 'hedge of thorns' (v.13), or the concept of 'betrothal' (v.14)?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern context, 'whoring' refers to spiritual unfaithfulness, not literal sexual acts
The 'hedge of thorns' (v.13) is a barrier that traps the people, symbolizing God's protection from their own sin
Betrothal in ancient Israel was a binding commitment that could last a lifetime, but here it's a new beginning

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'returning to God' from this passage this week?
tips: Identify one area where you have 'strayed' from God and consider how to 'return'
Pray for the strength to be 'betrothed' to God in righteousness and mercy
Commit to a specific step of restoration this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of restoration and the call to return to God.
tips: Thank God for His promise to restore His people
Ask for the courage to repent from unfaithfulness
Pray for the Holy Spirit to guide you into the new betrothal with Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 3:1-5 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Hosea's love for Gomer and the specific price mentioned.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'love' in verses 1-2
Pay attention to the phrase 'fifteen shekels of silver and a homer and a lethech of barley' (v2) as the cost of redemption
Listen for the promise of dwelling together without sin (v3)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Hosea) does WHAT (redeems Gomer), WHERE (in the context of Hosea's life as a metaphor for Israel), and WHY (to show God's love for His unfaithful people).
tips: Include Hosea's purchase of Gomer for 15 shekels and a homer of barley (v2)
Note the promise that Gomer will dwell with him for many days (v3)
Describe the future restoration of Israel (v5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the price of redemption (v2), the promise of dwelling together (v3), or the hope of Israel's return (v5)?
tips: The specific price (15 shekels) shows the cost of redemption, like Christ's blood
The promise that 'you shall dwell as mine for many days' emphasizes God's enduring love
The phrase 'afterward the children of Israel shall return' points to future hope in the Messiah

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: Hosea is showing that God redeems His unfaithful people (Israel) despite their idolatry
The price of redemption (v2) prefigures Christ's atoning sacrifice
The hope of restoration (v5) points to the coming of the Messiah as David's king

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The price of redemption, the period of waiting, and the reference to David's kingdom?
tips: The 'fifteen shekels' and barley are specific measures that show the cost of redemption, but they are a type of Christ's blood
The phrase 'dwell many days without king or prince' refers to a period of restoration, not a permanent state of chaos
The 'David their king' refers to the Messiah (the Son of David) who will rule over the restored kingdom

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Hosea redeemed his wife with a specific price. What situation requires you to trust God's redemption this week?
tips: Consider an area where you have been unfaithful to God and need to be redeemed
Think about what you are willing to 'buy' (sacrifice) to be redeemed by God
How can you be like Hosea in loving someone who has been unfaithful (even when it's costly)?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His love that redeems us, ask for courage to return to Him, and pray for the hope of the Messiah.
tips: Thank God for the price of redemption (Christ's blood)
Pray for the courage to return to God when you feel unfaithful
Ask for the hope of the Messiah as the true David

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 5:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of God's judgment and the repeated phrase 'Ephraim' in verses 5-6.
tips: Note the phrase 'Ephraim has played the whore' (v.5) - a strong metaphor for idolatry
Pay attention to the repetition of 'seeking' in the context of failure to find God
The phrase 'I will return again to my place' (v.15) shows God's patience

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (northern Israel, specifically Ephraim), WHAT they have done (defiled themselves through idolatry), WHERE this judgment occurs (in the land of Israel), and WHY God is acting (because of their unfaithfulness and rejection of Him).
tips: Ephraim has become a 'whore' (idolatry) as described in v.5
The priests are rebuked for their failure to lead the people back to God (v.1)
God has withdrawn His presence (v.4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'Ephraim has played the whore' (v.5), 'the pride of Israel testifies to his face' (v.6), or 'I will return again to my place' (v.15)?
tips: 'Ephraim has played the whore' is a powerful metaphor for total spiritual corruption
'The pride of Israel testifies to his face' shows that their own pride is evidence of their sin
'I will return again to my place' indicates God's patience and the promise of future restoration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel about their unfaithfulness and the need for repentance?
tips: Hosea warns that without repentance, God will continue to withdraw His presence
This passage shows that God's judgment is a response to persistent idolatry and unfaithfulness
The ultimate hope is that in their distress, they will seek God and find Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The use of 'whore' as a metaphor, why God withdraws until they seek Him, and the meaning of 'Ephraim' in this context?
tips: 'Whore' (Hebrew: 'mashpah') is a metaphor for unfaithfulness and idolatry in ancient Near Eastern context
God's withdrawal (v.4) means He is not actively working in their lives to save them until they repent
In Hosea, 'Ephraim' refers to the northern kingdom (the tribe of Ephraim) which was the dominant part of northern Israel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Hosea says that in our distress, we can seek God and find Him. What situation requires you to seek God this week?
tips: When you feel distant from God, take time to pray and seek Him
In moments of failure or sin, remember that God withdraws until you seek Him
Pray for the courage to seek God in your current distress

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He withdraws until we seek Him. Ask for the strength to seek Him in distress.
tips: Thank God for His patience and for the promise that He will return to His people in their distress
Pray for the humility to admit sin and seek Him
Ask God to help you find Him when you are in a state of distress

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 6:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the call to return, the third-day resurrection imagery, and the repeated question about Ephraim and Judah.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'What shall I do with you, O Ephraim? What shall I do with you, O Judah?' (v.3) showing deep lament
Pay attention to the phrase 'on the third day he will raise us up' (v.2) as a promise of resurrection
Notice the contrast between 'steadfast love' (v.6) and 'sacrifice'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (northern Israel) is being called to return, WHAT they have done (turned away from God), WHERE this call is happening (in the heart of the people), and WHY Hosea is writing this (to restore them through repentance).
tips: Include the phrase 'like Adam they transgressed the covenant' (v.8) as a reference to their unfaithfulness
Note the promise of healing and resurrection (v.2)
Mention the contrast of 'steadfast love' over ritual sacrifices (v.6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of the passage resonated most with you? Consider: the call to return (v.1), the third-day resurrection (v.2), the morning cloud metaphor (v.4), or the contrast of steadfast love vs. sacrifice (v.6)?
tips: The third-day resurrection promise: a hope of new life after judgment
The morning cloud metaphor: love that is fleeting but necessary for restoration
The phrase 'I desire steadfast love and not sacrifice' (v.6) challenges the religious system of the time

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage about the need for repentance and restoration?
tips: Northern Israel has been unfaithful (like Adam) and has turned away from God
God's response is not punishment but restoration: healing, resurrection, and renewal
The key is to return to the LORD with steadfast love, not ritualistic sacrifice

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are confusing? Consider cultural context, Hebrew terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The phrase 'he has torn us' (v.1) refers to the brokenness of the covenant due to sin, not physical tearing
The third-day resurrection is a common theme in Hebrew prophecy but here it's about God's active restoration of Israel
The term 'steadfast love' (hesed) in Hebrew is a covenant love that is more than just ritual sacrifice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to return to the LORD with steadfast love in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you've been focusing on religious rituals instead of genuine love for God
Pray for the 'third day' of God's healing in your life (a period of waiting for restoration)
Actively seek to know God as the 'dawn' (light) and the 'spring rain' (life-giving)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about Hosea 6's call to repentance and restoration.
tips: Thank God for His promise of resurrection and renewal
Ask for the strength to return to Him with steadfast love
Pray for the northern kingdom (Israel) to be restored

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 7:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the metaphors of the oven and the cake.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'he knows it not' (v.13 and v.15)
Pay attention to the phrase 'Ephraim is like a dove, silly and without sense' (v.14)
Listen for the emotional tone of despair and warning

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being judged, WHAT they are doing, WHERE this is happening (the spiritual condition), and WHY God is warning them.
tips: Include the three key metaphors: the oven (v.5), the cake not turned (v.5), and the gray hairs (v.13)
Note that Ephraim is turning to foreign powers (Egypt and Assyria) for help
Highlight the consequence: destruction and rebellion against God

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the oven metaphor (v.5), Ephraim as a cake not turned (v.5), or the gray hairs (v.13).
tips: The oven metaphor shows the nation's spiritual stagnation without divine intervention
Ephra:im as a cake not turned illustrates the failure to be shaped by God's work in their lives
The gray hairs represent the nation's aging and decay without awareness of their spiritual condition

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: Hosea warns that Ephraim's iniquity has led to their destruction because they have turned away from God and sought help from foreign powers
The passage shows that God's people must turn to Him for redemption, not to human or foreign powers
This passage foreshadows the need for Christ as the only Redeemer (as stated in the Christ connection)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphors of the oven and the cake, the meaning of 'gray hairs', and the connection to foreign powers.
tips: The oven metaphor (v.5) refers to spiritual decay without divine intervention; in ancient Israel, ovens were used for baking bread, and the baker (God) ceasing to stir the fire means the nation is lef
Ephraim mixing with other peoples (v.12) means the nation is seeking alliances with foreign nations (Egypt and Assyria) for protection, but these alliances are destructive
Gray hairs (v.13) symbolize the aging and decline of the nation without awareness, indicating spiritual blindness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of being 'a cake not turned' (v.5) to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel you are not being shaped by God (like the cake left unattended)
Pray for God to stir your heart and work in you, so you become 'turned' (molded) by His grace
Commit to one step of surrender to God rather than seeking help from other sources

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of iniquity and the need for redemption.
tips: Thank God for His love that He still seeks to redeem us despite our sin
Ask for the courage to turn away from idolatry and trust in Christ as the only Redeemer
Pray for awareness of spiritual decay (like the gray hairs) and the grace to seek God's help

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 9:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and repeated phrases such as 'wanderers' and 'Ephraim'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'wanderers' in verse 10
Pay attention to the phrase 'the days of punishment have come' in verse 9

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (northern Israel/Ephraim) is being warned, what they have done (forsaken God), where they are going (to Egypt), and why (their great iniquity).
tips: Include the key phrase: 'they have played the whore' (v. 1)
Note that they are becoming wanderers among nations (v. 10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of their sin (v. 1-2), the consequence of playing the whore (v. 3-4), or the image of being a wanderer (v. 10-11)?
tips: The phrase 'Ephraim was a watchman with my God' (v. 7) shows their betrayal of trust
The image of 'a fowler's snare' (v. 8) is a powerful metaphor for being caught in their own sin
The declaration 'they shall not remain in the land of the LORD' (v. 9) is a clear warning of exile

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage of warning?
tips: Hosea emphasizes that their idolatry has led to divine punishment and exile
The main point is that God will not save them if they turn away from Him
This warning foreshadows the ultimate redemption through Christ who gathers the scattered

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The term 'fowler's snare' (v. 8), the phrase 'wanderers among nations' (v. 10), or the connection to Egypt (v. 10)?
tips: A 'fowler's snare' (Hebrew: mizpah) refers to a trap set by a hunter, indicating that Ephraim is being caught in their own sin
Wanderers among nations (v. 10) means they will be displaced and live as strangers in foreign lands
Ephraim returning to Egypt (v. 10) is a specific historical context of northern Israel being forced to seek refuge in Egypt during the Assyrian threat

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Hosea says that Israel will become wanderers. How can you apply this to your current situation? What step can you take this week to avoid becoming a wanderer?
tips: Consider if you are holding on to something that makes you 'wander' (e.g., false security)
Pray for the strength to choose God over idols
Commit to one area where you can 'be a watchman' for God (v. 7) this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His warning and ask for strength to avoid becoming a wanderer, and pray for the community of believers to be gathered by Christ.
tips: Thank God that He sees our sin and will provide redemption
Pray for the strength to choose God over idols
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help us be watchmen for His purposes

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 10:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the vine imagery and the call to sow righteousness.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'you have plowed iniquity' (v.12) and the phrase 'sow righteousness' (v.12)
Pay attention to the emotional tone: from the luxuriant vine to the thorn and thistle

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (northern Israel) does WHAT (builds altars and pillars, utters false words) WHERE (in their land) and WHY (because they have a false heart and do not fear the LORD).
tips: Include the consequence: the destruction of altars and pillars
Note the call to sow righteousness and seek the LORD

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the vine imagery (v.1), the false heart (v.1), the call to sow righteousness (v.12), or the thorn and thistle (v.12)?
tips: The phrase 'thorn and thistle shall grow up on their altars' (v.12) is powerful because it shows the destruction of their worship places
The command 'sow righteousness' (v.12) is a call to active spiritual work, not passive waiting

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: Hosea is warning northern Israel that their false worship and idolatry have led to God's judgment
The main point is that without a true relationship with the LORD, their nation will be destroyed and they must turn to God to receive righteousness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'thorn and thistle' (v.12) or the concept of 'sowing righteousness' (v.12)?
tips: Thorn and thistle (v.12) is a metaphor for the natural growth of weeds that choke out the good things (the altars of worship)
Sowing righteousness (v.12) is an active command that requires intentional spiritual practice, not just passive faith

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'sowing righteousness' (v.12). What can you do this week to sow righteousness in your life?
tips: Identify one area where you've been 'plowing iniquity' (v.13) and take a step to 'reap steadfast love' (v.12)
Break up your 'fallow ground' (v.12) by doing one act of kindness this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He provides righteousness through Christ and ask for the courage to sow it.
tips: Ask God to help you break up the 'fallow ground' of sin in your life
Pray for the courage to 'sow righteousness' and to 'reap steadfast love'

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 12:1-14 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'the LORD is the God of the Israelites' and the metaphor of Ephraim feeding on the wind.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD is the God of the Israelites' (vv. 1-3) which emphasizes God's covenantal relationship
Pay attention to the phrase 'Ephraim feeds on the wind' (v. 4) as a metaphor for empty prosperity
The phrase 'I will again make you dwell in tents' (v. 13) shows God's promise of restoration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is being addressed (Ephraim/northern Israel), WHAT they are doing (feeding on wind, making covenants with foreign powers), WHERE this is happening (in the land of northern Israel), and WHY God is punishing them (for false prosperity and violence).
tips: Include the accusation that Ephraim 'feeds on the wind' (v. 4) as a sign of empty prosperity
Note the contrast between Ephraim's wealth and the 'false balances' (v. 12)
Mention God's promise to restore them to tents (v. 13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the metaphor of 'feeding on the wind' (v. 4), the wrestling of Jacob (v. 10), or the promise of dwelling in tents (v. 13)?
tips: The metaphor 'Ephraim feeds on the wind' (v. 4) shows their false prosperity and spiritual emptiness
Jacob's wrestling with God (v. 10) is a powerful image of perseverance and divine encounter
The promise 'I will again make you dwell in tents' (v. 13) is a hopeful reminder of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: Hosea warns Ephraim that their false prosperity and alliances with foreign powers (like Assyria) cause them to lose their identity as God's people
The passage emphasizes God's unbroken covenant and promise of restoration through faithfulness
This passage connects Israel's national identity with the story of Jacob (Genesis) as a model of God's relationship

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphor of 'feeding on the wind', the connection to Jacob's story, or the promise of dwelling in tents?
tips: 'Feeding on the wind' (v. 4) is a metaphor for empty prosperity lacking substance, common in ancient Near Eastern culture
The reference to Jacob wrestling with God (v. 10) is a Genesis story used as a type for Israel's relationship with God
The promise of dwelling in tents (v. 13) recalls Israel's wilderness experience but shows God's ongoing care

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this to your life this week? Focus on God's promise of restoration for those who turn back.
tips: Identify an area where you feel you are 'feeding on the wind' (empty prosperity) and seek God's help to be rooted in truth
Pray for courage to 'return' to God (v. 13) when you feel lost
Commit to 'holding fast to love and justice' (v. 12) in your daily actions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about God's promise of restoration for Ephraim. Ask for the strength to turn back to God.
tips: Thank God for His promise to restore His people (v. 13)
Pray for strength to overcome the 'false balances' of sin in your life
Ask God to help you 'wait continually for Him' (v. 12) in difficult times

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 13:1-15 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone and specific metaphors used in the chapter.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'morning mist' and 'dew that goes early away' (v.2) - shows fleeting sin
Pay attention to the lion and bear metaphors (v.3-4) - God's active destruction
Notice the phrase 'I am the LORD your God' (v.4) - declares God's uniqueness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is being judged, what they have done, where this judgment is happening (theological context), and why God is acting.
tips: Include Ephraim's idolatry and making metal images (v.1-2)
Note the reference to forgetting God in the wilderness (v.4)
Describe God's declaration of their destruction (v.2-3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the morning mist metaphor (v.2), the lion and bear imagery (v.3-4), or God's declaration about death and Sheol (v.14-15).
tips: The metaphor of 'morning mist' (v.2) - shows how quickly their sin disappears without lasting impact
The image of God as a lion that 'will fall upon them' (v.3) - emphasizes God's active and destructive judgment
The declaration 'O Death, where are your plagues? O Sheol, where is your sting?' (v.14) - shows God's victory over death

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel about their idolatry and the consequences of turning away from God?
tips: Hosea warns that northern Israel's idolatry leads to destruction but God remains their only savior
The theological significance: God's sovereignty over death and promise of redemption through Him
This passage foreshadows Christ's victory over death (1 Cor 15:55)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts in this chapter.
tips: The phrase 'they have made for themselves metal images' (v.2) - in ancient Israel, metal images were associated with idolatry (Baal) but the Hebrew term specifies crafted idols
The metaphor of 'like a lion' (v.3) - in Hebrew, the lion represents power and danger, not a gentle approach
The concept of 'Sheol' (v.14) - the Hebrew term for the underworld, distinct from Christian concepts of hell

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Hosea warns that idolatry leads to destruction. What area of your life needs to be purified from idolatry this week?
tips: Identify one area where you might be turning away from God (like making idols in your heart)
Practice daily confession of sin and seeking God's presence
Ask God to 'ransom' you from death through His sacrifice (v.15)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's judgment on idolatry and His redemption through Christ, as described in Hosea 13.
tips: Thank God that He is the only savior (v.4)
Ask for the strength to resist idolatry in your life
Pray that God will 'ransom' you from death (v.15) through His sacrifice

chapters.chapterTitle: A Plea to Return to the LORD

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Hosea 14:1-10 aloud, focusing on the plea for return and the promises of restoration.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Return, O Israel' (v1)
Pay attention to the contrast between 'Assyria shall not save us' (v4) and God's provision
The phrase 'I will heal their apostasy' (v5) is a key promise

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (northern Israel/Ephraim) is called to do WHAT (return to the LORD), WHERE (in their land), and WHY (because of their iniquity and apostasy).
tips: Include the call to return with words (v1-2)
Note the promise of healing apostasy (v5) and restoration (v6-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plea for return (v1), the dew imagery (v5), or the evergreen cypress (v7).
tips: The dew imagery: 'I will be like the dew to Israel' (v5) - a promise of renewal and cleansing
The evergreen cypress: 'I am like an evergreen cypress' (v7) - a symbol of eternal life and provision
The promise of the orphan finding mercy (v7) - a compassionate God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Hosea trying to communicate to northern Israel through this passage?
tips: Hosea calls for repentance and return to the LORD, promising restoration and healing for their apostasy
This passage emphasizes God's grace and mercy in contrast to the people's idolatry and sin
The restoration is conditional on the people returning to the LORD

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The call to return when the people have already sinned? The role of Assyria? The nature of 'healing apostasy'?
tips: 'Apostasy' refers to a deliberate turning away from God, which was common in northern Israel
Assyria is the enemy that the people are warned not to rely on (v4) - this is a warning against false security
The promise of healing apostasy (v5) is a promise of God's redemptive power in the midst of sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This passage calls for returning to the LORD with words of repentance. What step can you take this week to return to God?
tips: Pray for the strength to return to God when you feel distant
Confess specific sins that have led to your separation from God
Read Hosea 14:1-2 and ask God to help you return with words of repentance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise to heal our apostasy and restore us. Ask for the courage to return to Him.
tips: Thank God for His mercy to the orphan (v7)
Ask for the grace to return to Him despite our sin
Pray for the strength to be like the evergreen cypress (v7) - enduring and fruitful
